article:
'Exaptation', '[[Co-option (biology)|co-option]]', and '[[preadaptation]]' are
related terms referring to shifts in the function of a trait during evolution.
For example, a trait can evolve because it served one particular function, but
subsequently it may come to serve another. Exaptations are common in both
anatomy and behaviour. Bird feathers are a classic example: initially these may
have evolved for temperature regulation, but later were adapted for flight.
Interest in exaptation relates to both the process and products of evolution:
the process that creates complex traits and the products (functions, anatomical
structures, biochemicals, etc) that may be imperfectly developed. {{cite web
  | last = first = authorlink = coauthors = title =Preadaptation work =
